channel.title: Cant share my rsps?
channel.description: Ok, So I have some questions. First I have set up portforwarding and how do I share my rsps after portforwarding? I already set everything to my no-ip and I put my client drop box and gave it to a friend. Then after he got it I ran my server and he started the client but it wouldnt load anything else. It just said loading 0%. So then I tried giving him my source also and that just gave him errors because like error! "main" something like that. This is in the same house. So what im trying to say is how do I share my rsps? Everywhere I see they all say portforward and then your friends can join, but they dont add the step on how to join it -_-. If I sound dumb or anything its because I just started doing this yesterday.

item.title: Cant share my rsps?
item.dc:creator: @Ole_Kristian Ole Kristian
item.description:
@Ole_Kristian wrote:

[quote] [quote] [quote] [quote] [quote] Hello! If I'm not horribly mistaken, the client's Client.java/Client.class-file contains the IP-address of the server it's going to look for.

Portforwarding should only be necessary when clients are going to access you’r server from outside it’s LAN (WAN), where the Socket-connection
needs to know wich port it shall try to connect trough.

Do you know how you’r server is accepting incoming Socket-connections?
[/quote]

ummmm, im sorry but cant find any ip in client.java and there is no client.class file for my source or client. Sorry again but I dont know what a socket connection is. Also do I just make a client.jar and send it in drop box because I did that and it didnt load, it kept saying loading 0%. Thx for responding!
[/quote]

Hmmm… Just exactly wich RSPS-revision are we talking about?
For the moment I’m deeply concentrated in my 317 project.

Could you enter you’r source, open up “Server.java” and copy/paste it’s “run”-method in a new comment below?
Most RSPS are making connections to their clients in this method.
[/quote]

What do you mean? I searched and there is no server.java, the only thing that shows is server channel handler. Im making a 712+ rsps
[/quote]

Strange… Do you know wich class contains you’r server’s main-method?
[/quote]

thx for helping but im uninterested in making a rsps now

OH - That’s unfortunate!
How ever, if you ever want to create an RSPS again, perhaps you should try a lower revision.

Read full topic

item.title: Cant share my rsps?
item.dc:creator: @ninjastorm ninjastorm
item.description:
@ninjastorm wrote:

[quote=“Ole Kristian, post:6, topic:544734”][quote]

Hello! If I’m not horribly mistaken, the client’s Client.java/Client.class-file contains the IP-address of the server it’s going to look for.

Portforwarding should only be necessary when clients are going to access you’r server from outside it’s LAN (WAN), where the Socket-connection
needs to know wich port it shall try to connect trough.

Do you know how you’r server is accepting incoming Socket-connections?

ummmm, im sorry but cant find any ip in client.java and there is no client.class file for my source or client. Sorry again but I dont know what a socket connection is. Also do I just make a client.jar and send it in drop box because I did that and it didnt load, it kept saying loading 0%. Thx for responding!

Hmmm… Just exactly wich RSPS-revision are we talking about?
For the moment I’m deeply concentrated in my 317 project.

Could you enter you’r source, open up “Server.java” and copy/paste it’s “run”-method in a new comment below?
Most RSPS are making connections to their clients in this method.

What do you mean? I searched and there is no server.java, the only thing that shows is server channel handler. Im making a 712+ rsps
[/quote]

Strange… Do you know wich class contains you’r server’s main-method?[/quote]

thx for helping but im uninterested in making a rsps now

Read full topic

@Ashi wrote:

You can’t use no-ip
